title: Burton Joyce Walks

images.title: Stephen McKay / Burton Joyce Monuments
images.caption: Burton Joyce Monuments. Contrasting styles of monuments alongside the A612 in Burton Joyce; the one in the foreground commemorates the Queen's silver jubilee in 1977, the more substantial brick affair behind was built for the millennium.

images.title: Alan Murray-Rust / Maize on Burton Meadows
images.caption: Maize on Burton Meadows. This was in the process of being harvested; unfortunately the machine was out of sight on the far side of the field.

images.title: johnfromnotts / Trent Lane looking East towards Bulcote & Gunthorpe
images.caption: Trent Lane looking East towards Bulcote and Gunthorpe

images.title: Alan Murray-Rust / Burton bend
images.caption: Burton bend. The River Trent describes almost a complete semicircle in making its way past Burton Joyce.

images.title: Alan Murray-Rust / Burton Meadows
images.caption: Burton Meadows. A man walks his dogs through maize stubble in evening sunshine.

images.title: Gunthorpe toll house by Richard Croft, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Gunthorpe toll house

images.title: Alan Murray-Rust / Traffic lights, Gunthorpe Lock
images.caption: Traffic lights, Gunthorpe Lock. During the off-season it is fine to leave lock operation to boaters, but in season the presence of a lock keeper to manage traffic is vital.

description: This Nottinghamshire village has some nice riverside trails and peaceful footpaths across the Burton Meadows. This walk takes you east to visit the neighbouring village of Gunthorpe . The walk starts on the southern side of the village where you can pick up a country lane taking you east across Burton Meadows. You then come to Gunthorpe where you can pick up a section of the Trent Valley Way to take you along the river to the pretty Gunthorpe Lock. The route then returns to Burton Joyce following an alternative riverside footpath through Burton Meadows.
